snippet.title: WRAP Angelie Jolie news conference on flood victims, meets PM
snippet.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Wide of US actress and goodwill ambassador for the United Nations's refugee agency, Angelina Jolie, entering meeting room and shaking hands with Pakistan Minister of State for Foreign Affair Nawabzada Malik Amad Khan 
2. Close of Jolie 
3. Mid of Jolie shaking hands with Government officials 
4. Cutaway of photographer
5. Wide of Pakistan Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gillani entering room and shaking hands with Jolie
6. Close of Jolie
7. Close of Yousaf Raza Gillani
8. Various of meeting.
9. Various of Jolie arriving for news conference
10. Wide of Jolie sitting down for news conference 
11. Various of Jolie just before news conference begins
12. Various of Jolie at news conference
13. SOUNDBITE (English) Angelina Jolie, US actress:
"Something happens then you have to assess for an appeal, then you make an appeal, then you wait for the money to come in for the appeal, then you try to.. and all the time, people are waiting to just have basic survival, so we have to find a way to get money and more tools put in place, before disasters hit. And so this is a bigger question of how the international community and the UN function when it comes to this and what we need to do."
14. Cutaway of Jolie's hand 
15. Close-up of Jolie's face 
16. Wide of news conference
17. SOUNDBITE (English) Angelina Jolie, US actress:
"Of course not, of course not. I have hardly the words that somebody would do that to somebody's religious book."
18. Mid of news conference 
19. Pan of Jolie leaving after news conference
STORYLINE
Angelina Jolie on Wednesday condemned a Florida church's threat to burn copies of the Quran to mark the ninth anniversary of the September 11 attacks.
The 35-year-old actress spoke out against the proposed burning during a trip to Pakistan to raise awareness about the floods that have devastated the largely Muslim country over the last six weeks. 
She visited in her capacity as a goodwill ambassador for the United Nations's refugee agency, meeting with Pakistan's Prime Minister, Yousaf Raza Gillani and other government officials on Wednesday afternoon.
Jolie's criticism echoed that of top US officials, who have described the church's plan as a disgraceful act and have even warned that it could endanger US troops in Afghanistan and Americans worldwide.
"I have hardly the words that somebody would do that to somebody's religious book," Jolie told reporters in Islamabad after visiting refugees camps in northwestern Pakistan - one of the areas of the country hit hardest by the floods.
The Christian minister organising the Quran burning, Pastor Terry Jones, has said he plans to go ahead in spite of concerns. 
He is part of the Dove World Outreach Centre, a tiny, evangelical Christian church in Gainesville, Florida, with an anti-Islam philosophy.
The issue has not received much attention in Pakistan, where officials and residents have been trying to cope with the devastation caused by floods that first hit the country at the end of July following extremely heavy monsoon rains.
The floods began in the northwest at the end of July after extremely heavy monsoon rains and slowly surged south along the Indus River, swallowing up hundreds of villages and towns and killing more than 1,700 people. 
Another 17 (m) million have been affected by the floods, and many will need emergency assistance to survive.
Jolie, who wore a long dress and covered her hair with a black scarf in keeping with local Muslim custom, expressed her shock at the height the floodwaters had reached.

localized.title: WRAP Angelie Jolie news conference on flood victims, meets PM
localized.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Wide of US actress and goodwill ambassador for the United Nations's refugee agency, Angelina Jolie, entering meeting room and shaking hands with Pakistan Minister of State for Foreign Affair Nawabzada Malik Amad Khan 
2. Close of Jolie 
3. Mid of Jolie shaking hands with Government officials 
4. Cutaway of photographer
5. Wide of Pakistan Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gillani entering room and shaking hands with Jolie
6. Close of Jolie
7. Close of Yousaf Raza Gillani
8. Various of meeting.
9. Various of Jolie arriving for news conference
10. Wide of Jolie sitting down for news conference 
11. Various of Jolie just before news conference begins
12. Various of Jolie at news conference
13. SOUNDBITE (English) Angelina Jolie, US actress:
"Something happens then you have to assess for an appeal, then you make an appeal, then you wait for the money to come in for the appeal, then you try to.. and all the time, people are waiting to just have basic survival, so we have to find a way to get money and more tools put in place, before disasters hit. And so this is a bigger question of how the international community and the UN function when it comes to this and what we need to do."
14. Cutaway of Jolie's hand 
15. Close-up of Jolie's face 
16. Wide of news conference
17. SOUNDBITE (English) Angelina Jolie, US actress:
"Of course not, of course not. I have hardly the words that somebody would do that to somebody's religious book."
18. Mid of news conference 
19. Pan of Jolie leaving after news conference
STORYLINE
Angelina Jolie on Wednesday condemned a Florida church's threat to burn copies of the Quran to mark the ninth anniversary of the September 11 attacks.
The 35-year-old actress spoke out against the proposed burning during a trip to Pakistan to raise awareness about the floods that have devastated the largely Muslim country over the last six weeks. 
She visited in her capacity as a goodwill ambassador for the United Nations's refugee agency, meeting with Pakistan's Prime Minister, Yousaf Raza Gillani and other government officials on Wednesday afternoon.
Jolie's criticism echoed that of top US officials, who have described the church's plan as a disgraceful act and have even warned that it could endanger US troops in Afghanistan and Americans worldwide.
"I have hardly the words that somebody would do that to somebody's religious book," Jolie told reporters in Islamabad after visiting refugees camps in northwestern Pakistan - one of the areas of the country hit hardest by the floods.
The Christian minister organising the Quran burning, Pastor Terry Jones, has said he plans to go ahead in spite of concerns. 
He is part of the Dove World Outreach Centre, a tiny, evangelical Christian church in Gainesville, Florida, with an anti-Islam philosophy.
The issue has not received much attention in Pakistan, where officials and residents have been trying to cope with the devastation caused by floods that first hit the country at the end of July following extremely heavy monsoon rains.
The floods began in the northwest at the end of July after extremely heavy monsoon rains and slowly surged south along the Indus River, swallowing up hundreds of villages and towns and killing more than 1,700 people. 
Another 17 (m) million have been affected by the floods, and many will need emergency assistance to survive.
Jolie, who wore a long dress and covered her hair with a black scarf in keeping with local Muslim custom, expressed her shock at the height the floodwaters had reached.
"We have to find a way to get money and more tools put in place, before disasters hit. And so this is a bigger question of how the international community and the UN function when it comes to this and what we need to do," she said.

snippet.title: Aftermath of floods that have killed more than 900 people
snippet.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Wide of houses and dead buffalos under flood water
2. Man pushing dead buffalo with stick in flood water
3. Dead buffalo in water
4. Various of cow standing on roof of house
5. Villager Habib Khan leading buffalo away from flood area
6. SOUNDBITE: (Pashto) Habib Khan, local villager:
"My two oxen, eight buffalos and two cows have died in the floods, just found one alive, I am coming back from a safe place where the water level was low, this buffalo has been kept in the second floor of a house for three days."
7. Wide of timber shop with men standing in flood water
8. Timber shop owner collecting wood from water
9. Planks of wood covered in mud
10. SOUNDBITE: (Urdu) Shair Dad, timber shop owner:
"I haven't covered my losses in ten years, we are buying this wood on credit, I don't know how I will be able pay it back"
11. Wide of area under flood water
STORYLINE
Rescue workers struggled on Sunday to save more than 27,000 people still trapped by massive flooding in Pakistan's northwest that has killed over 900 people and destroyed thousands of homes, officials said.
The effort has been aided by a slackening of the monsoon rains that have caused the worst flooding in decades in Khyber-Pakhtoonkhwa province. 
But as flood waters have started to recede, authorities have begun to understand the full scale of the disaster.
In Nowshera city - where water levels were dropping on Sunday - some people were slowly making their way back to their houses.
Shair Dad, a timber shop owner, said his business has been badly affected by the floods.
"I haven't covered my losses in ten years, we are buying this wood on credit, I don't know how I will be able pay it back," he said on Sunday.
The death toll from the flooding has risen to 903 people, said Mujahid Khan, the head of rescue services for the Edhi Foundation, a private charity.
The worst hit areas have been the districts of Swat and Shangla, where more than 400 people have died, he said.
Authorities have deployed 43 military helicopters and over 100 boats to try to rescue some 27,300 people still trapped by the floods.       
The military has deployed 30,000 army troops who had evacuated 19,000 trapped people by Saturday night, said an army spokesman. 
But the scale of the disaster has strained the resources of a government already grappling with a faltering economy and a brutal war against the Taliban.
The floods have caused an acute shortage of fruits and vegetables in the northwest because many of the hardest hit areas were the key centres of production, officials said.
The threat of disease loomed as well as some evacuees arrived in temporary camps with fever, diarrhea and skin problems.
A variety of nations and aid organisations have begun to mobilise a response to the flood disaster.
The US delivered 380,000 food packages, four rescue boats and two water filtration units to the Provincial Disaster Management Authority, said a spokesman for the Provincial Disaster Management Authority.
The US Embassy in Islamabad has also announced it will provide 12 prefabricated steel bridges to temporarily replace some of the spans damaged by the water.
Floodwaters were receding in the northwest, Pakistani officials said, but fresh rains were expected to lash other parts of the country in the coming days.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/7da343e1357b0bb25d7a3d9571210bcf 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

snippet.title: Latest on floods in Punjab, mother with sick child
snippet.description:
1. Various of people attempting to cross floodwater holding rope 
2. Wide of damaged road under flowing floodwater 
3. Mid of people carrying belongings walking through floodwater 
4. Wide of Ghulam Hafeeza walking through floodwater with her three children, one of them sick
5. SOUNDBITE: (Saraiki Native Language) Ghulam Hafeeza, flood victim:
"My son has been suffering from vomiting and diarrhoea since yesterday. Last night I took him to the hospital and he was injected with (IV) drips all night. I spent the whole night in hospital. Today in the morning the doctor advised me to take him to Muzaffarghar hospital. How I can go? Nobody is with me, floodwater is everywhere. I don't have money. My house and everything was swept away. I have two sons and one daughter. I am carrying my children and finding my way."
6. Close-up of Hafeeza holding sick child, her daughter next to her
7. Over the shoulder shot Hafeeza walking holding sick child
8. Various of people walking through floodwater
9. Various of school inundated in floodwater 
10. Close-up of flood victims standing and laying beside rail track 
STORYLINE
More rain soaked flood-ravaged Pakistan on Saturday and even heavier downpours were forecast for coming days, deepening a crisis which Pakistani officials estimate as affected as many as 13 million (m) people throughout the South Asian nation.
About 1,500 people have died, most of them in the northwest, the hardest-hit region. 
Mass evacuations are under way in the southern province of Sindh after the Indus River rose there.
The intense flooding that began about two weeks ago has washed away roads, bridges and many communications lines, hampering rescue efforts. 
Incessant monsoon rains have grounded many helicopters trying to rescue people and ferry aid, including six choppers manned by US troops on loan from Afghanistan.
Floodwaters receded somewhat on Friday in the northwest, but downpours in the evening and early Saturday again swelled rivers and streams. 
Pakistani meteorologists said heavy rains in Afghanistan were expected to make things even worse over the next 36 hours as the bloated Kabul River surged into Pakistan's northwest.
That will likely mean more woes for Punjab and Sindh provinces as well, as new river torrents flow east and south.
In the northwest and Punjab, floods have displaced 12 million (m) people, said an official with the National Disaster Management Authority. 
In the Punjab city of Kot Addu, flood victim Ghulam Hafeeza walked through floodwaters with her three children, one of them sick, trying to make it to a hospital almost 90 kilometres (60 miles) from where she was. 
"My son has been suffering from vomiting and diarrhoea since yesterday. Last night I took him to the hospital and he was injected with (IV) drips all night. I spent the whole night in hospital," she explained through tears. 
The hospital she took her son to, the Government Civil Hospital of Kot Addu, has also been badly affected by the floods so a doctor advised her to travel the long distance to the Muzaffarghar hospital to get care for her sick child.
"How I can go? Nobody is with me, floodwater is everywhere. I don't have money. My house and everything was swept away. I have two sons and one daughter. I am carrying my children and finding my way," a desperate Hafeeza said as she continued her journey. 
Nearby, some attempted to cross raging floodwaters using ropes while others carried their belongings through knee deep water. 
In Sindh province, about 1 million (m) people have been evacuated or are being helped out of their homes, said the provincial irrigation minister.
Authorities have given varying tolls for the number of people among Pakistan's 175 million (m) impacted by the floods.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/43e5d4e5c9d12d609306e27bbc059587 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

snippet.title: Field hospital struggles to cope with flood victims
snippet.description:
SHOTLIST
Government Technical College IDP (Internally Displaced Person) camp
1. Wide exterior of Flood Field Hospital compound, ambulance passing through (AUDIO: siren)
2. Close of sign (Urdu: "Flood Field Hospital, health department Mardan"
3. Wide of interior, doctors treating patients
4. Mid of volunteers giving first aid to a wounded patient
5. Mid of doctor checking a female patient
6. SOUNDBITE (Urdu) Gulzar Hussain, camp doctor:
"We are treating patients with diarrhoea everyday and send them back to their tents or home, but we have not identified any case of cholera here yet".
7. Cutaway, doctor writing a prescription
8. SOUNDBITE (Urdu) Gulzar Hussain, camp doctor:
"In the camp the necessary things we need are medicine and equipment. If we have updated equipments then we can treat the patients well. An ambulance is also very important as the day before yesterday there was a case of delivery and we didn't have a vehicle here at that time so we used a World Health Organisation vehicle which was here at that time. We sent the patient to Mardan DHQ (District Headquarters) Hospital".
9. Mid of female patient on bed with her new-born twins
10. Close up of twins 
11. Mid of patients in bed
12. Wide pan right of ward
13. Low angle of a woman fanning her ill child
14. Wide pan left of tents
STORYLINE:
Medical staff at a field hospital in Nowshera district, requested more medicine and equipment on Saturday, as they continued to try and treat the sick and injured civilians displaced by the flooding.  
"In the camp the necessary things we need are medicine and equipment. If we have updated equipments then we can treat the patients well," said 
Gulzar Hussain, a doctor struggling to run the field hospital at a government technical college in Nowshera, 27 miles east of Peshawar in the country's Northwest.
"The day before yesterday," he said, "There was a case for delivery (birth) and we didn't have a vehicle here."
However, he said that although they have treated many cases of diarrhoea, so far they had not identified any cases of cholera.
The UN High Commission for Refugees said it provides shelter to over 500 families in the Nowshera District and its emergency facility will eventually hold up to 3,000 people affected by the floods. 
World Health Organisation (WHO) said more than 200 health centres or hospitals across the country had been damaged on destroyed in the floods.
Around 150-thousand people are reported to have joined the mass exodus of the Indus River flood plains on Saturday, as floodwaters continued to rise.
In the southern Sindh province, 600-thousand people have set-up relief camps as a result of flooding over the past month.
The waters have washed away houses, roads and crops and smashed key communication and transport infrastructures.
Officials expect the floodwaters will recede nationwide in the next few days as the last river torrents empty into the Arabian Sea. 
The United Nations Food Programme's Pakistan country director, Wolfgang Herbinger, said on Saturday that the programme needs at least 40 more helicopters to reach the large number of people cut off by the flooding.
The floods have affected about one-fifth of Pakistan's territory, straining its civilian government as it also struggles against al-Qaida and Taliban violence.
At least 8 (m) million people are in need of water, shelter or other emergency assistance, making the disaster larger than Pakistan's last two humanitarian crises, the exodus from Swat last year amid an army offensive against the Taliban and the 2005 Kashmir earthquake.
The country's textile industry is also expected to suffer because of damage to cotton crops.
Already, the prices of vegetables, meat and dairy products have risen sharply across the country.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/484d5f38d54e8146a294d690d3fa2cb6 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

snippet.title: Flood displaced struggle in disaster zone, crops damaged
snippet.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Sick girl lying on table inside a makeshift camp set up at an educational institute in Tando Bago town
2. Pan of (women and children displaced by floods) inside a classroom
3. Mid shot woman carrying baby 
4. Various of flood victims sitting in corridor
5. SOUNDBITE (Sindhi) Bibi Mero, Flood Victim:
"We are not receiving any relief goods, even not a single five kilogram bag of flour. Now the government is telling us that we should get out from here, our houses have been inundated with floodwater. What can we do?"
6. Various of women washing dishes in dirty water and mud
7. Water being distributed to flood-affected people
8. People waiting to get water
9. Close of sign board, reading (English) "Government Monotechnic Institute of Tando Bago"
10. Various of flooded cotton field
11. Various of woman walking in flooded field
12. SOUNDBITE (Urdu) Ali Bakhs Shah, Local farmer:
"Our main cotton crop has been spoiled and 90 to 99 percent of our remaining seasonal rice crop has also been spoiled. The sugarcane crop which was ready for delivery to sugar mills has been 90 percent affected (by the floods), there might be some sugarcane left in some upper part of field, if they have been cultivated on higher grounds. The chili and onion have been totally spoiled, all crops are gone, even there is no grass left for cattle."
13. Various of flooded chili field
14. Close of rice plants in floodwater
15. Various of farmers in rice field
STORYLINE
More than 200 people have died, 200-thousand have been left homeless and 4.2 (m) million acres of agricultural land have been inundated, as heavy flooding spreads across Pakistan''s Sindh province.
The town of Tando Bago, in Badin district - the worst hit district around 200 kilometres (124 miles) from Karachi - is under several feet of water in places, making it impossible for residents to return to their homes.
Affected families in Tando Bago were given shelter in a makeshift camp set up at an educational institute.
Bibi Mero, a flood victim seeking shelter at the institute, complained that they were not receiving enough aid from the Pakistani government. 
"We are not receiving any relief goods, even not a single five kilogram bag of flour," she said.
The floods began early last month (August), but heavy rains have compounded them recently and hampered relief efforts.
Four-point-two (m) million acres of agricultural land has also been inundated, authorities said, devastating (m) millions of US dollars worth of crops.
Local farmers in the Sindh province are once again facing huge financial losses with rice, cotton and sugarcane crops ruined.
Last year, southern Pakistan was hardest hit by massive floods that swamped much of the country, killing 2,000 people.
The United Nations, meanwhile, is rushing food and tents to Pakistan after Islamabad formally asked for foreign assistance this weekend. 
Japan and China have also pledged relief goods or money, according to the Pakistan government. 
The United States said it had paid for food packages for 23-thousand families, and that its local partners would soon begin handing out tents, clean water and other supplies.
The return of the floods is testament to the heaviness of the monsoon rains that lash much of South Asia from June to September, as well as the limits of Pakistan''s weak and corrupt government.
As they did last year, the floods are undercutting the legitimacy of the shaky government, which is already widely disliked and struggling against Islamist militants, ever present political turmoil and massive economic problems.

STORYLINE
More than 200 people have died, 200-thousand have been left homeless and 4.2 (m) million acres of agricultural land have been inundated, as heavy flooding spreads across Pakistan''s Sindh province.
The town of Tando Bago, in Badin district - the worst hit district around 200 kilometres (124 miles) from Karachi - is under several feet of water in places, making it impossible for residents to return to their homes.
Affected families in Tando Bago were given shelter in a makeshift camp set up at an educational institute.
Bibi Mero, a flood victim seeking shelter at the institute, complained that they were not receiving enough aid from the Pakistani government. 
"We are not receiving any relief goods, even not a single five kilogram bag of flour," she said.
The floods began early last month (August), but heavy rains have compounded them recently and hampered relief efforts.
Four-point-two (m) million acres of agricultural land has also been inundated, authorities said, devastating (m) millions of US dollars worth of crops.
Local farmers in the Sindh province are once again facing huge financial losses with rice, cotton and sugarcane crops ruined.
Last year, southern Pakistan was hardest hit by massive floods that swamped much of the country, killing 2,000 people.
The United Nations, meanwhile, is rushing food and tents to Pakistan after Islamabad formally asked for foreign assistance this weekend. 
Japan and China have also pledged relief goods or money, according to the Pakistan government. 
The United States said it had paid for food packages for 23-thousand families, and that its local partners would soon begin handing out tents, clean water and other supplies.
The return of the floods is testament to the heaviness of the monsoon rains that lash much of South Asia from June to September, as well as the limits of Pakistan''s weak and corrupt government.
As they did last year, the floods are undercutting the legitimacy of the shaky government, which is already widely disliked and struggling against Islamist militants, ever present political turmoil and massive economic problems.

snippet.title: AP focus on one family's efforts to cope with flood disaster
snippet.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Various of BiBi Shehnaz, who lost her child while fleeing floods, holding her second child
2. Wide of Shehnaz sitting with others on a cot
3. SOUNDBITE (Pashto) BiBi Shehnaz, Mother who lost her son in floods:
"While we were sleeping I heard a loud voice of a villager warning us to run because the floods were coming. While I was trying to flee, a child of mine was slipped away from my hands and was swept away by the gushing water, I do not know his whereabouts yet."
4. Shehnaz and others taking shelter from rain
5. Woman rushing for shelter to avoid rain
6. Flood victims bringing their cattle inside for shelter from rain
7. Pan from people under shelter to rain outside
8. Various of people walking in rain
9. Various of cattle and people taking shelter from rain
10. Various of flood victims cooking food
11. Close of children
12. SOUNDBITE (Pashto) Abdul Rehman, Local Resident:
"Government hasn't done enough for us, I will appeal to the government at least to help the children."
13. Wide of entrance to college building being used as camp for flood victims
14. Close of college sign reading (English), "College Charsadda"
15. Various of food distribution among flood victims
16. Pan of tents setup for flood victims
STORYLINE
Fresh downpours hit Pakistan's devastated northwest Tuesday, as flood waters submerged dozens of villages along bloated rivers whose torrents have killed at least 1,500 people and put thousand more at risk of disease. 
Of the 3.2 (m) million people affected by flooding, 2.5 (m) million live in the northwest, a UNICEF spokesman told reporters in Geneva.
In the Peshawar district of Charsadda on Tuesday residents were struggling to come to grips with the devastation of the worst flooding in generations.
Many sought cover from the new rains Tuesday as they huddled, many with their livestock at makeshift shelters and relief points.
At one such shelter a woman who had lost her son in the floods described the moment she felt her little one's hand slip away from hers. 
"While we were sleeping I heard a loud voice of a villager warning us to run because the floods were coming. While I was trying to flee, a child of mine was slipped away from my hands and was swept away by the gushing water," BiBi Shehnaz said.
"I do not know his whereabouts yet," she said, recounting a tale that has become all too familiar in the region. 
The fresh rains in the hardest-hit northwest threatened to overwhelm a major dam and unleash a new deluge.
Relief work for some 3.2 million people has been delayed by swamped roads, washed-out bridges and downed communication lines, and survivors have complained about government inaction. 
"Government hasn't done enough for us, I will appeal to the government at least to help the children," said one villager Tuesday. 
The loss of so many crops was one reason the UN's World Food Program estimated that some 1.8 (m) million Pakistanis would need food assistance for at least the next month.
Aside from farmers, many victims have small businesses that have been destroyed and won't have the means to buy food for their families, a WFP
(World Food Programme) spokeswoman said in Geneva.
The northwest is the epicentre of Pakistan's battle against al-Qaida and the Taliban. 
Alongside military and police operations, the government - with the support of the West - has tried to improve its services and living standards there to blunt the appeal of militancy.
The Pakistani army, which has the helicopters, boats and infrastructure needed for relief work, is delivering food, medicine and tents, as are government agencies and several different political parties and welfare organisations.
But many flood victims were unhappy with the response.

Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

snippet.title: Help Restore Drinking Water to Pakistan’s Snow Leopard Conservation Communities
snippet.description: Hundreds of people in northern Pakistan are without drinking water and shelter after recent floods devastated their homes. Communities that have partnered with us to protect the endangered snow leopard for years have been hit particularly hard. They urgently need help to restore water supply and housing! snippet.title: Profile of woman who lost husband and children in floods
snippet.description:
1. Low angle shot of flood victim Hayatan Bi Bi walking towards her tent with her mother
2. Hayatan Bi Bi entering tent
3. Wide interior of tent showing Hayatan sitting with her family
4. Mid of Hayatan's husband and mother inside tent
5 Close up of Hayatan's son
6. Wide of Hayatan with her family inside tent
7. Hayatan with her baby girl
8. Close up of Hayatan's baby girl sleeping 
9. SOUNDBITE: (Sindhi) Hayatan Bi Bi, lost her two sons and father in flooding:
"When flood water came to our village every one one was running, my father took my two sons and ran. I followed my father with my other kids, I saw a vehicle and boarded it with my kids but my father and two sons had been taken away by flood water. I reached this camp with my other family member's and now I live in this camp."
9. Close up of Hayatan 
10. Low angle of Hayatan and her kids
11. Wide of tent village
12. Mid of tent village, children sitting on cart
13. Mid of child with his mother in tent village
14. Close up of child
15. Wide of tent village
16. Young girl hanging cloths
17. Various of children swimming in flood water
18. Various top shots of tent village
STORYLINE:
Driven from their homes by Pakistan's devastating floods, hundreds of thousands of people in Sindh province have been housed in tented camps.
At one camp in Sukkur Sindh on Wednesday morning Hayatan Bi Bi spoke of her loss, her two sons and father dragged away by raging flood waters.
"When flood water came to our village every one one was running, my father took my two sons and ran," she recounted, sitting with her mother, husband and other children at the makeshift camp.
"I followed my father with my other kids, I saw a vehicle and boarded it with my kids but my father and two sons had been taken away by flood water."
Hayatan said she lost all her possessions and she and her family are now reliant on government aid. 
Floods have isolated about 800,000 people in Pakistan who are now only reachable by air and aid workers need at
least 40 more helicopters to ferry lifesaving aid to the increasingly desperate people, the United Nations said.
The appeal on Tuesday was an indication of the massive problems facing the relief effort in Pakistan more than three weeks after the floods hit the country, affecting more than 17 million (m) people and raising concerns about possible social unrest and political instability.
The floods began with hammering monsoon rains in the northwest and have swept southwards.
The aid group World Vision said it could be three months until some families are able to return to their homes.
Local charities, the Pakistani army and international agencies are providing food, water, medicine and shelter to the displaced, but millions (m) have received little or no help.
The UN High Commissioner for Refugees estimates that about 700,000 Pakistanis have been forced into makeshift settlements just in the southern province of Sindh.
Earlier, Prime Minister Yousuf Raza Gilani said hundreds of health facilities had been damaged and tens of thousands of medical workers displaced and the country's chief meteorologist warned that it would be two weeks until the Indus River, the focus of the flooding still sweeping through the country, returns to normal levels.
The death toll in the floods had been around 1,500 people but they rank as one of Pakistan's worst ever disasters
because of their scale and the massive economic damage, especially to the country's vital agricultural sector.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/5fea714be377435ecb7a9daac33c2ec4 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

snippet.title: Waterborne diseases such as cholera spreading after floods
snippet.description:
NB STORY IS NOT ON TAPE
1. Guarded entrance to Dera Ismail Khan district hospital 
2. Close of D I Khan hospital sign 
3. Wide exterior of people entering hospital
4. People entering children's ward where flood-affected children admitted
5. Wide of children's ward
6. Various of doctor checking flood-affected children
7. SOUNDBITE: (Saraiki) Nafeesa Bi Bi, mother of child patient:
"Floods totally destroyed our village and houses, our children have become sick. The government must help us out.''
8. Mother with her sick child in hospital bed
9. SOUNDBITE (Urdu) Fazal Rehman, doctor at DI Khan hospital:
''The recent flood was very devastating. Most of the children coming to us have diarrhoea and vomiting. We have treated 100 to 200 patients. Most of them have been discharged, but we are giving treatment to 30 to 50 patients on a daily basis.''
10. Various of mothers with sick children in ward
11. Wide of children's ward
STORYLINE:
As Pakistan's authorities on Monday warned of more flooding to come in the week ahead, flood victims, particularly children, are beginning to contract water-borne diseases.
Hundreds of people suffering from diarrhoea and vomiting reported to to the Dera Ismail Khan government hospital in Peshawar on Monday.
Medical staff at the hospital in north west Pakistan said they have limited beds to admit patients, and the priority was sick children.
"We have treated 100 to 200 patients. Most of them have been discharged, but we are giving treatment to 30 to 50 patients on a daily basis,'' said Doctor Fazal Rehman.
Cholera, which can spread rapidly after floods and other disasters, poses a dangerous threat.
The disease has been detected in the northwest, but there have been only a few reported cases so far.
Pakistan's worst floods in recorded history began more than two weeks ago in the mountainous northwest and have spread throughout the country. 
Some 20 (m) million people and 160,000 square kilometres (61,776 miles) of land - about one fifth of the country - have been affected.
The scale of the disaster has raised concerns it could destabilise the country, which is pivotal to US hopes of defeating al-Qaida and the Taliban, has a weak and unpopular government, and an anaemic economy propped up by international assistance.
The United Nations has appealed for an initial 460 (m) million US dollars to provide relief, of which around 60 percent has been given.
Once the floods recede, (b) billions more will be needed for reconstruction and getting people back to work in the already-poor nation of 170 (m) million people. 
While local charities and international agencies have helped hundreds of thousands of people with food, water, shelter and medical treatment, the scale of the disaster has meant that many millions have received little or no assistance. 
The UN has voiced fears that disease in overcrowded and unsanitary relief camps may yet cause more deaths.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/d76f34f5c32fa9da1dddb98e24d6d843 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

snippet.title: Army uses helicopters to drop aid into severely flooded areas
snippet.description:
The Pakistani army on Sunday air-dropped relief supplies to villagers stranded by floodwaters in the Multan district of the eastern province of Punjab.
Military and civilian rescuers have been using helicopters and boats to evacuate people since 3 September, when monsoon rains triggered flooding.
"Our houses were inundated by floodwater four days ago. When a helicopter drops food, sometimes we get it - sometimes food is wasted," said Mohamamd Sadaqat, a resident of Multan district who had to abandon his home. 
Pakistan's disaster management agency said it would blow up another protective dike in an attempt to spare the city of Muzaffargagh.
Seventeen people were killed when a boat carrying a wedding party sank near the city of Multan. 
Separately, three people drowned in the same area overnight, according to rescue officials. 
The deaths, combined with those from the boat tragedy, brought the overall death toll from the flooding in Pakistan to 301.
The disaster management agency said the heavy rains and flooding had also injured more than 500 people in Pakistan and Pakistani-administered Kashmir, adding that more than two million people had been affected.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/1b6e352cfb96a0cddae8832d9a769447 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

snippet.title: Monsoon rains kill at least 136 people in the south, floods
snippet.description:
1. Wide overhead view of Karachi street with rain pouring down
2. Mid overhead view on street with cars driving through the rain
3. Close overhead view of people standing by side of road in the rain
4. Close overhead of children in the rain
5. Mid of people standing by a vehicle on a flooded street, one of them holding an umbrella
6. Mid of two people pushing a motorbike through floodwaters
7. Various of people pushing cars through floodwaters
8. Mid of boy sitting on motorbike as man wheels bike through flooded street
9. Mid of vehicles driving along flooded street
10. Close low shot of floodwaters falling into a drain
11. SOUNDBITE (Urdu) vox pop, Abdul Quddoos, Karachi resident:
"We are facing numerous problems as transport vanished from the streets. Roads are filled with rain water touching knee level. And families are suffering. No efforts were seen from the government to improve the situation. 
12. Mid of police officers standing knee deep in floodwaters, cars splashing through behind them
13. Mid of people and vehicles moving slowly through flooded street
14. Various of vehicles moving slowly in traffic jam on flooded street
15. Mid of hospital ward interior, pan left to people lying on hospital beds, man being treated
16. Mid of man lying on hospital bed being checked
17. Various of patients lying on beds, some with bandages
18. Wide of hospital exterior, with floodwaters in front of building
STORYLINE:
Monsoon rains which inundated the southern Pakistani city of Karachi on Saturday claimed at least nine lives and injured many more, hospital sources said. 
A police surgeon at the city''s Civil Hospital Dr Hamid Paryar told the Associated Press that they were electrocuted in rain related incidents.
Several injured bikers were rushed to different hospitals, as dozens of motorcycles skidded on slippery roads in various areas of the city.
Commuters were stuck in traffic jams for several hours and many vehicles ran out of petrol as heavy rain lashed Pakistan''s largest city. 
The rains in southern Pakistan began in early August 12 and have affected some 170,000 acres of agricultural land.
A Pakistani relief official said earlier this week the monsoon rains in the south of the country have killed 136 people.
Monsoon season in Pakistan usually lasts until the middle of September.

events.title: Colombia: Floods and Landslides, Spring 2015
events.description: Flooding, windstorms and landslides affected more than 20,000 people in Colombia in April 2015. The rainy season in the southern and western departments had a particularly strong impact in the Amazonas department near the Peruvian and Brazilian border.

snippet.title: Colombia: Search for landslide survivors continues in Antioquia
snippet.description:
At least 52 people were killed and dozens were injured in Antioquia province in north-west Colombia on Monday, after houses were buried by mud and submerged in water as a result of a landslide. 

According to local media, the search for a number of missing people continues, while residents are on alert because there are fears of another landslide. 

Footage Courtesy of: Gobernación de Antioquia

snippet.title: Thousands of homes damaged in deadly floods
snippet.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Wide of flooded street in neighbourhood on the outskirts of Bogota
2. Residents being evacuated in an inflatable boat 
3. Emergency worker helping crying woman through floodwater after leaving her house 
4. Emergency workers carrying children from boat onto dry land 
5. SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) Sandra Patricia Salamanca, resident in flooded building:
"We have spent the last three days in the water, three days. They are telling us to evacuate, to leave the place but who is going to watch over the apartments that we are leaving behind?"
6. Flooded main street
7. Women carrying belongings out of their homes 
8. Partly submerged car 
9. Residents walking next to flooded apartment blocks 
10. More residents being evacuated by boat 
11. Wide of flooded area 
12. Police officers carrying resident's belongings through water  
13. Residents who live in upper floods returning to their homes, being dropped off by police boat  
14. Wide of flooded area 
STORYLINE
Flooding caused by heavy rains has forced the evacuation of at least 3,500 families from their homes on the outskirts of the Colombian capital, officials said.
Police officers and emergency workers helped dozens of families to leave their apartments in a neighbourhood south of Bogota on Thursday.
Those living in ground and first floor apartments were evacuated in boats provided by Bogota's emergency services.
Residents tried to take as many personal belongings with them as they could, but many refused to leave, fearing that their properties would be looted.
The second rainy season of the year has caused floods in various parts of northwest and central Colombia.
The rainfall has not been as intense as last year nor as bad as it was in early 2011, but the land still has not been able to absorb the extra water. 
There have also been several landslides in the region in the last 48 hours, which have damaged roads and blocked transit routes.
A hillside loosened by rain collapsed on a bus in northeastern Colombia killing at least three people, officials said.
A Red Cross rescue director said two other people were trapped in the bus late on Tuesday.
Officials say 105 people have died in flooding and landslides since the second rainy season began on September 1.
Colombia has two rainy seasons every year: the first one starts in March and ends in June, the second one lasts from September until December.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/1c28923935d7d9509f9b8d0d07e3f5a1

snippet.title: Colombia: Landslides and Land Mines
snippet.description:
Rescue efforts are continuing in the village of Salgar, where residents were deluged with tons of mud and water on Monday, taking the lives of at least 60 people and injuring dozens. The worst natural disaster of its kind in more than a decade prompted President Juan Manuel Santos to declare a national emergency. As many as 48 people are still missing. Also in Colombia, a pilot project to clear land mines and explosive devices is underway in the state of Antioquia. An operation being carried out by the Colombian Army and the FARC guerrillas was agreed upon in the Havana peace talks. The first steps are being taken in the areas with the most victims. Out of 11,000 registered since 1999, as many as 2,500 are in Antioquia.  The pilot project consists of six stages, the first of which was the selection of the initial regions, and it is being followed by the Identification of the characteristics of the region. The deactivation and removal will be carried out by a special battalion of the army, accompanied by FARC rebels, who will show the troops where the land mines are located. Natalia Margarita reports from Colombia for teleSUR. 
 http://multimedia.telesurtv.net/v/colombia-landslides-and-land-mines/

snippet.title: Colombia: Death Toll at 56 in Mudslide
snippet.description:
The number of people killed by a landslide in Colombia has risen to 56. Dozens more are missing after mud and heaving rains brought trees crashing down on homes and streets in the village of Salgar. Residents described feeling the ground shake and houses being carried away by the currents. The search continues for survivors amidst the rubble. Military personnel are assisting in the rescue efforts, as are workers from the Department of Risk Management, who are awaiting humanitarian aid. teleSUR  
 http://multimedia.telesurtv.net/v/colombia-death-toll-at-56-in-mudslide/

snippet.description: Al menos 17 comunidades campesinas del municipio de Ovejas, en el departamento de Sucre, Colombia podrían ser desplazadas ante la sequía que enfrentan aunado al abandono gubernamental. Pobladores de la región aseguran que no hay "una sola gota de agua" para consumo humano ni alimento suficiente para las familias, mientras el gobierno "no suministra ayuda alguna". teleSUR http://multimedia.telesurtv.net/v/colombia-17-comunidades-en-peligro-por-sequia-y-abandono-del-gobierno/

snippet.title: Colombia: Efforts Continue to Rescue Trapped Miners
snippet.description: Colombian rescue teams continue to search for the miners trapped in a flooded gold mine in the western department of Caldas. Five bodies have already been recovered. teleSUR http://multimedia.telesurtv.net/v/colombia-efforts-continue-to-rescue-trapped-miners/

snippet.title: Colombia: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang touts bilateral free trade zone
snippet.description:
Chinese Premier Li Keqiang stressed that plans to begin research into the establishment of a free trade zone between China and Colombia signalled that trade between the two nations would "expand to a very large scale." He made the comments during a joint press conference with Colombian President Juan Manuel Santos in Bogota, Friday.

snippet.title: President prepared to mediate an end to Colombia-FARC conflict
snippet.description:
25 June, 2010
1. Wide of Ecuadorean President Rafael Correa during interview
2. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Rafael Correa, President of Ecuador: 
"For any peaceful solution, non-violent, yes, count us in. If we can mediate, if we can serve as facilitators, count on us. It destroys our soul, the civil war that's been going on for so many decades, the absurd spilling of blood among brothers."
3. Cutaway of Correa being interviewed
4. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Rafael Correa, President of Ecuador:
"Ecuador would like a clear answer, a clear apology from President Santos (Colombian President Elect Juan Manuel Santos) as president (Alvaro) Uribe has already done in order to get over this serious incident, because we can't 'try to cover the sun with one finger' and it is not that we look at the past bitterly, we look at the past with outrage. It was very serious what happened on March 1st 2008 and to normalise the relationship (between Colombia and Ecuador) we would like to clear this thing once and for all with a declaration (from the Colombian state) that this will not happen again."
5. Cutaway of Correa being interviewed
6. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Rafael Correa, President of Ecuador:
"We won't take orders from anybody telling us with whom we can establish relationships or not."
(Q: Will you then strengthen the relationship with Iran?)
"Of course, as we will do with Russia, China, the US, Colombia or Venezuela.... with any country of the world with whom we can have bilateral relations based on mutual respect"
7. Cutaway of Correa being interviewed
8. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Rafael Correa, President of Ecuador: 
"We need our own forum to deal with our problems, without the unbalancing presence of the United States. The US is itself, 50 states. And nobody is questioning them being there or the existence of that unbalancing power but we need to discuss our things among equals, discuss realities closer to our realities, shared visions and so on and that's why we need our own institutions to solve the conflicts."
26 June, 2010
++QUALITY AS INCOMING++
9. Correa greeting Bolivian president Evo Morales, with Venezuelan president Hugo Chavez behind them 
10. Wide of main table with leaders of the ALBA group 
11. Close of Correa and Chavez talking 
12. Wide of gathering
13. Child giving Morales and Correa a flag, child hugging Correa 
12. Wide of meeting 
13. Child talking to Correa 
14. Pull out from statue of Simon Bolivar, hero of independence wars in Latin America, to wide of meeting
STORYLINE 
Ecuador's President Rafael Correa has said he would be happy to help mediate an end to Colombia's long-running conflict with leftist rebels, declaring on Friday that the conflict was an "absurd spilling of blood among brothers.".
He also said in an interview with The Associated Press Friday that he'd be pleased to attend the inauguration of Colombian President-elect Juan Manuel Santos next month, despite the fact that diplomatic ties between the two neighbouring countries have not been fully restored and he has not received any formal invitation.
Ecuador broke off relations with Colombia after its military crossed into Ecuador in March 2008 and attacked the jungle camp of top Colombian rebel leader Raul Reyes, killing him and 24 others in a pre-dawn raid.
An Ecuadorean judge last month issued an arrest warrant for Santos, who was Colombia's defence minister at the time.
Santos won the presidency by a landslide last Sunday with 69 percent of the vote. 
He has called the arrest warrant absurd because it was the Colombian state, not him as an individual, which made the cross-border incursion. 
He merely authorised it as defence minister, he said in an interview three days before his election.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/d36aacdac49ba07ce54d2933bfdd0d20 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

snippet.title: Thousands Attend Colombia Mass Funeral
snippet.description:
For more WORLD NEWS "SUBSCRIBE" US

A mass funeral has taken place in the Colombian town of Salgar for victims of a devastating mudslide on Monday.
Burials were held for 33 of the 84 people whose bodies have been recovered. Several local people are still missing.
Thousands of people gathered in the square outside the town's main church to pay their respects in front of a long row of coffins.
Rescue workers are still searching the local river for victims.
One resident of Salgar particularly hard hit is the city's cemetery worker who has prepared 15 graves for members of his own family - mostly cousins who died in the flood.

A spokesman for the national emergency authorities said he expected to end the search for victims on Thursday or Friday.
He said between 20 and 25 local people caught in the flood had not been accounted for.
Locals and firefighters have been searching a 40km-long (25 mile) stretch of land on the banks of the Liboriana river.

snippet.title: 60 Dead in Colombia Mudslide
snippet.description: The death toll from the massive mudslide early Monday morning in the northwestern state of Antioquia has now topped 60. The heavy rains and mud have hampered rescue efforts and the exact number of victims is still unknown. A state of emergency has been declared in the village of Salgar. Also in Antioquia, demining operations have begun with the participation of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) and specialists from other countries. In a major step forward for the peace process, the Colombian government, rebels, and the affected communities will work toger to rid the countryside of landmines. teleSUR http://multimedia.telesurtv.net/v/60-dead-in-colombia-mudslide/

snippet.title: 5 Afghans trained by Colombians in counter drug measures
snippet.description:
SHOTLIST
1. US soldiers taking part in the training 
2. Soldiers marching 
3. Various of soldiers receiving instructions from commander   
4. Various of soldiers patrolling 
5. SOUNDBITE: (English) Sergeant Abdul Najid Haldary, Afghan Soldier:
"It's not easy. I came from so far, like from Asia, to here. I came here to work hard, not for resting. If I wanted to rest, I can rest in my home, in my country."
6. Translator interpreting questions for Afghan soldiers 
7. SOUNDBITE: (Farsi) Sergeant Muhammad Nouroz, Afghan soldier:
"I'm a Sergeant, I have been working with the police for two years specifically in counter narcotics."
8. Afghan soldiers patrolling 
9. Various of Afghan soldiers
STORYLINE
Members of Afghanistan's counter-narcotics police officers are being trained by their more experienced Colombian counterparts in the fight against drugs. 
The cooperation between the two countries was already in place, but for the first time the Afghan officers are now participating in the training, which is taking place on a police base in Ibague, the capital of the western Colombian department of Tolima, focuses mainly on finding and attacking drug labs. 
The Afghan officers, selected by their government to participate in the programme, are working very hard to learn as much as possible from their Colombian trainers.
"It's not easy. I came from so far, like from Asia to here. I came here to work hard, not for resting. If  I wanted to rest, I can rest in my home, in my country, said Sergeant Abdul Najid Haldary.
Afghanistan is currently struggling to control its drug trade, especially opium. 
An estimated 93 percent of the world's opium comes from Afghanistan, bringing in as much as 2 (b) billion US dollars (1.5 (b) billion euro) a year in profits.
Experts say booming profits from the lucrative crop are being used to fuel the Taliban. 
Colombia, on the other hand, has a long history of battling drug cartels.
The country remains remains the source of more than 90 percent of the world's cocaine, despite the recent unprecedented aerial fumigation of coca crops across the country.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/2011c8ba36a6bbcab62fa8908e11127d

snippet.title: Police checking reports of computers stolen at Honduran embassy party
snippet.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Exterior of entrance of Honduras Embassy in Colombia: (Spanish) "Honduras Embassy."
2. Close of embassy sign at gate reading (Spanish) "Honduras Embassy."
3. Wide exteriors of Honduras embassy 
4. Wide exteriors of Bogota Metropolitan Police building
5. Mid of Colombian Police Col. Jose Elias Baquero talking to reporters
6. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Col. Jose Elias Baquero, Colombian Police:
"Immediately (after finding out about stolen computers) police offered this government official (Jorge Mendoza, in charge of Honduran Embassy in Colombia) judicial services and the ability to make a complaint with the Bogota Metropolitan police, but this gentleman immediately declined to file a complaint with the police and said that this matter would be handled internally in the embassy."
7. Wide exteriors of embassy
8. Close of Honduran flag
STORYLINE
Colombian police say they are investigating reports that at least two computers were stolen during a party at the Honduran Embassy in Bogota that involved presumed
prostitutes.
Police Col. Jose Elias Baquero said police were searching for what he described as two "contracted women" who attended the 20 December party.
He says Honduran officials have confirmed that there was a party in which two laptop computers were stolen, but that they prefered to handle the matter internally.
According to Baquero after police were informed of an "abnormal situation" at the embassy, they made contact  with Jorge Mendoza, an official who is described as being "in charge at the time of the embassy."
Baquero says that Mendoza confirmed to police that there was a party during which two laptops were stolen. 
According to Baquero, Mendoza also said there were women hired to be at the party from a neighbourhood in northern Bogota known, among other things, for having many brothels.
Colombian police say they have drawn sketches of the presumed prostitutes, but Mendoza declined to make any identifications. 
Eight investigators have been assigned to the case. 
The embassy did not respond to repeated calls seeking comment and the Foreign Ministry in Tegucigalpa said it may release information later.



You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/446b626ffd6aff47cecdfdb2e8920be7 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

snippet.title: Peace comissioner anounces peace measures with FARC, analyst
snippet.description:
AP FILE
Unknown location - Undated 
1. Various of FARC (Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia) troops 
Presidential VNR - No access Colombia
Bogota, 30 May 2006
2. SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) Luis Carlos Restrepo, Colombia's Peace Commissioner:
"Good afternoon everyone, this morning the President and his delegates met to explore the possibility of searching for new peace paths with the FARC (Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia). The government will proceed with all its will and decency to make this happen. Bogota, May 30th 2006. Thank you very much."
3. Mid shot of Colombia's peace commissioner Luis Carlos Restrepo after reading the statement
AP FILE 
Unknown location - Undated 
4. Various of FARC troops 
AP Television 
Bogota, 30 May 2006
5. SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) Vicente Torrijos, Analyst and Political Scholar from the University del Rosario: 
"President Uribe will try to approach and see to what extent the FARC will agree to a cease fire or a modification of its radical behaviour to proceed to a humanitarian exchange (of the political hostages). But if President Uribe doesn't get any answers from them (in order to reach an agreement ) he will come off to be as obstinate and radical as he has been so far during his presidency and as radical as the FARC is." 
6. Mid shot of political analyst walking away after the interview
AP FILE
Unknown location - Undated 
7. Various of FARC troops 
STORYLINE:
Colombian peace commissioner Luis Carlos Restrepo met the newly re-elected President Alvaro Uribe 
after relatives of kidnap victims chided the newly re-elected leader for not mentioning their loved ones in his victory speech. 
Restrepo said in a statement Uribe wanted to "search for new peace paths with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia," or FARC.
Uribe was re-elected Colombia's president after a landslide victory on Sunday in which he won 62 percent of the vote - 40 percent more than his nearest rival.
But in his 45-minute victory speech, Uribe failed to mention his strategy for bringing the leftist rebels to the negotiating table. 
Instead he focused on economic achievements like a free trade agreement reached with the United States.
The FARC is believe to hold more than 60 prominent hostages, including three American defence contractors captured when their small plane crashed into a FARC stronghold in the jungle in 2003.
A doubling of the defence budget and sharp increase in troop strength allowed the law-and-order Uribe to force the FARC to retreat into the jungle during his first term, helping to dramatically reduce what's still one of the world's highest kidnapping and murder rates.
Despite the military advances, most analysts believe it's impossible for the government to defeat the 15,000-strong guerrilla army on the battlefield. 
During the campaign, Uribe acknowledged the time for talks was approaching.
Analyst and political scholar from the University del Rosario, Vicente Torrijos said that " if President Uribe doesn't get any answers from them (in order to reach an agreement ) he will come off to be as obstinate and radical as he has been so far during his presidency and as radical as the FARC is." 
The FARC has resisted the government's peace attempts so far.
A few months ago, a proposal backed by France, Spain and Switzerland to exchange the hostages for FARC members held in prison failed to take off, with FARC leaders vowing they'd never strike a deal with Uribe.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/9d439d0fa4c5af91cc3d2345e5a06f47 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

snippet.title: Security preps ahead of President Bush arrival in Bogota
snippet.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Wide of Bogota
2. Pan right of buildings
3. Mid of police standing with Bogota behind 
4. Close of weapon
5. Soldier talking on a phone attached to mobile unit being carried by a colleague 
6. Wide of soldiers, one talking on the phone 
7. Mid of police officers walking on the streets 
8. Mid of military commander Luis Eduardo Perez standing close to the Colombian flag 
9. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Luis Eduardo Perez, Army commander of the 13th military brigade:
"Right now Bogota, is in a state of calm. We can say that according to our intelligence work there are no reports of any actions or threats against Bogota."
10. Mid of man reading a newspaper with the picture of US President George W. Bush on the front
11. Close of newspaper with picture of Bush 
12. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Juan Carlos Rios, Resident of Bogota:
"Well, the best thing that the President of the United States, Mr. Bush can bring to Colombia is peace and goodwill to Colombians."
13. Various of newspapers featuring Bush
14 Street scene
15. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Cecilia Pulido, Resident of Bogota:
"I think that he (Referring to president Bush) is a good person. He has helped my family a lot.
Question: Why?
Answer: Because everything we have is thanks to him as well as the situation of my sons in the United States."
15. Wide of graffiti that reads in Spanish "Bush out of Colombia. Yankee go home" and people passing by 
16. Mid of graffiti reading in English "Yankee go home"
17. Mid of street and graffiti reading in Spanish "Bush out of Colombia".
STORYLINE:
Thousands of police officers and soldiers patrolled the streets of Bogota on Sunday, ahead of US President George W. Bush's arrival in Colombia on the latest leg of his Latin American tour.
Luis Eduardo Perez, Army commander of the 13th military brigade told AP Television on Sunday that Bogota was calm.
"We can say that according to our  intelligence work there are no reports of any actions or threats against  Bogota," he said.
Armed troops and military vehicles have been posted at checkpoints on the  city's roads, some 30-thousand soldiers and police were deployed to patrol the streets and helicopters could be seen high above country's capital, surveying the city of nearly seven (m) million from above.
Bogota residents who spoke to AP Television had mixed views about President Bush's visit.
"The best thing that the President of the United States, Mr. Bush can bring to Colombia is peace and goodwill to Colombians," said Juan Carlos Rios.
"I think that he (Referring to president Bush) is a good person. He has helped my family a lot," added Cecilia Pulido. "Everything we have is thanks to him as well as the situation of my sons in the United States."
Graffiti in Bogota was less complimentary about Mr. Bush, with messages written in both English and Spanish calling for the president to go home.  
Bush has been travelling to US-friendly Latin American nations to shore up relations and highlight US aid to the region.
His tour got underway in Brazil on Friday and he was due to visit Uruguay and  Guatemala before returning home to the US.
Bush was scheduled to arrive in Colombia at 1205pm local time (1705GMT).

snippet.title: Honduran President Zalaya visits, Uribe on economy
snippet.description:
1. Wide shot of Colombian President Alvaro Uribe, right, and President of Honduras Manuel Zelaya, left, walking together in the Presidential Palace of Narino
2. Wide of both presidents during the playing of national anthems 
3. Close of military band playing trumpets 
4. Wide zoom in to both presidents walking together 
5. Zelaya taking hat
6. Set up of Zelaya and Uribe at news conference 
7. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Alvaro Uribe, President of Colombia:
"One of the lessons that we have learned from the financial crisis in Wall Street is that the lack of regulation can stimulate that wild horse which is the speculative capital, and that can cause a lot of damage.  Countries have to be able to guarantee the productive capital, and we see that speculative capital only works against the interests of productive capital."
8. Cutaway of both presidents standing at news conference 
9. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Manuel Zelaya, President of Honduras: 
"We just concluded a meeting between the presidents of Central America, where we came up with several economic policies based on austerity in spending, and of greater investment, in order to give solvency to the banking system, the same as what President Uribe is doing here.  Also we want give solvency to the creation of new investments in the region.  Honduras is also consolidating public investment, not only private investment, in order to use commerce as a complement to social activities, which today represent one of our main challenges." 
10. Wide of both presidents walking into the Presidential Palace. 
STORYLINE: 
The President of Honduras Manuel Zelaya met his Colombian counterpart Alvaro Uribe in Bogota on Thursday, where the two discussed economic policies in light of the global financial crisis.
Speaking at a joint news conference outside the Presidential Palace of Narino, Zelaya said the pair had just concluded a meeting with other presidents of central America to discuss the situation.
Sporting his trademark stenson hat, Zelaya said the meeting would see the implementation of policies that would allow "greater investment" to give the regions' banking system solvency, while promising "austerity" in government spending.
Uribe said the "financial crisis in Wall Street" had showed that a lack of regulation in financial markets could have disastrous consequences.
Latin American stocks have been hard hit by the crisis, which has already forced intervention from the governments of Brazil, Mexico and Colombia.
Analysts say the region is worried a global recession could reduce demand for regional commodities such as metals, oil and agricultural goods.

snippet.title: SYND 1/5/80 DOMINICAN EMBASSY SEIGE ENDS IN BOGOTA
snippet.description:
The 61-day siege of the Dominican embassy in Bogota ended peacefully on Sunday(27 April) when the guerrillas of the M-19 group, plus 16 hostages, left the building for Eldorado airport. Four diplomats were released before the flight to Havana and full political asylum for the militants. Colombian officials said that the negotiated solution to the tense stalemate included a privately raised payment of two million dollars and the prompt release of all remaining hostages upon landing in Havana. The final settlement was arranged during meetings held between a petite, hooded woman guerrilla and government officials. A team led by Dr Tom Farer and representing the organisation of American states' human rights commission later served as a mediating force, guaranteeing that military trials of leftists still in Colombian prisons would be monitored by the OAS.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/3e5fc8a40c7dd95d91e84b12e3908261 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

snippet.title: WRAP New morgue shots, comments from French forensic team
snippet.description:
Maracaibo - 18 Aug 2005
1. Wide truck with forensic equipment arriving at morgue
2. Medium of truck
3. Various equipment on truck
4. Truck with morgue in background
5. Equipment
6. Police wearing masks standing guard 
7. Medium of police
8. French forensic expert
9. Press interviewing another French expert
10. Antonio Rivero at presser
11. SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) Antonio Rivero, National Civil Defence chief:
"Today, we''re going to finish the third phase, which means taking a pan of the entire area, approximately 100 metres from the impact, to determine whether any remaining human bodies or remains, as determined by the speed and impact of the plane." 
12. Cutaway press

Maracaibo - 18 Aug 2005
13. Various of delegation from Martinique arriving at morgue site 
14. SOUNDBITE (French) Pierre Fuedil, Vice President, General Council Martinique: 
"The relatives of the victims are going to arrive tomorrow at seven o''clock. (he pauses) They''re due at seven o''clock." Q: What do you think will happen tomorrow? "We represent the Martinique authorities and we want to make sure the families are well received. I hope we''ll be able to tell them what happened, that they will find out the truth." 
15. Delegation entering morgue  

STORYLINE:

Teams from France and from the island of Martinique continued their investigation in Venezuela on Thursday into the crash of a passenger jet that killed all 160 on board. 

The jet was carrying 152 passengers home from Panama to Martinique, a French overseas department in the Caribbean, when it crashed on Tuesday in Venezuela. 

Forensic experts and equipment used to identify victims'' bodies arrived from France at the University of Zulia medical school in the western Venezuelan city of Maracaibo, where the bodies are being held in a morgue. 

Eight Colombian crew members were also killed in the crash.

Col. Antonio Rivero, the chief of Venezuela''s emergency agency, said workers on Thursday were continuing to search for dead bodies and human remains at the crash site.

Colombia has grounded the airline that chartered the flight from Martinique while its civil air authority reviewed inspections that the small carrier had been required to perform.

Teams of French experts travelled to Venezuela to aid in the investigation and help identify victims'' remains, officials said. 

A strong odour of decaying bodies permeated the air outside the medical school morgue in Maracaibo where the bodies were being identified.

Three refrigerated shipping containers were placed outside for the remains to be loaded once identified.

Three men and a woman arrived from Martinique at the morgue accompanied by the French consul and hurried inside without speaking to journalists who crowded around them. They were said to be representatives of victims'' families, sent to help identify remains.

Authorities in Martinique also are to appoint two investigative judges to determine if anyone bears legal blame.

Venezuelan investigators were focusing on the possibility of contaminated fuel or some other fuel problem that led both engines to fail simultaneously, said a Venezuelan emergency official.

Panamanian authorities, however, said they found no evidence of tainted fuel and that the plane had plenty of fuel for the trip.

The pilot radioed the nearest airport before the crash, saying both engines had failed, and requested permission for an emergency landing.

Officials said the plane apparently fell into a steep descent minutes later.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/6cf0d47f99967a3220df73d6598791f6 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

snippet.title: CUTS 9 10 80 BOLIVIAN REFUGEES
snippet.description:
At the end of September, Bolivia's military commanders constituted themselves as the country's supreme governming body through a statute that will keep them in power for at least three years. Since the coup, which overthrew President Lidia Gueiler Tejeda last July - the Bolivian junta seems to be increasingly isolated after its decision to leave the Andean pact and the condemnation of the coup by the Bolivian Catholic church. Meanwhile political and trade union militants are still leaving the country to go into exile.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/c5ceb0f0b9ddae990527f0984e4d0525

events.title: Rwanda: Floods and Landslides
events.description: On 3 April 2015, heavy rainfall caused flooding and landslides in Nyamasheke and Rubavu districts in Rwanda's Western Province.
